boardgame.name: Star Trek Game
boardgame.description:
The object of the game is to move your spaceship pawn from the Earth to three of six orbiting planets and be the first one to return to Earth. The game is played on a 36 by 36 grid with the Earth at the center. Players get fuel cards numbered 1 through 10 to control their movement. Each turn, you play one fuel card to move your ship that number of squares either horizontally or vertically, but not both.
There are also two fuel ships. Every player on his turn rolls a die and moves one of the fuel ships. If you land next to a fuel ship, you can retrieve any one used fuel card. When you are out of fuel, you can only move one square per turn. You also retrieve any 3 used fuel cards on every planet you land on.
Each planet has a series of 10 to 12 dots that describe its entry/exit orbit. To leave Earth, you have to follow the 12 orbit dots before you enter the vertical and horizontal grid of open space. Likewise, when you want to land on a planet, you have to start on the outermost orbit dot and follow the orbit down to the planet's surface. Sorry, no transporters in this game.

boardgame.name: Kaarten
Kaartspelen
Playing Cards
Traditional Card Games
boardgame.description:
Traditional Card Games is not an individual game, but a game system including games that can be played with a traditional deck(s) of cards.

This database entry covers all card games that can be played with a standard deck of cards. Not all card games played with standard playing cards can be mentioned separately in BGG's database, and many regional card games that aren't as widespread as popular games like Poker or Blackjack.

The standard deck playing card games page lists many of the card games that are listed separately in the BoardGameGeek database. Many are also included in the list of games belonging to the Traditional Card Games family.

A "karma card" decides which realm the player is to be reborn into. The idea is to escape from the wheel and become a Buddha - once you've done that you can opt to go back in to help other players and prolong the game into infinity.

boardgame.name: Das Gurkensolo
boardgame.description:
The game features a race of four wooden cucumbers along 12 numbered fields. Each player draws a card showing the order in which the cucumbers should pass the finishing line.
In every turn each player picks two cards containing statements about the race's standings, e.g. "The red cucumber is not ahead of the green cucumber." Now the player must choose one cucumber to move forward by one field or two, if he succeeds in making one of the two statements true and the other one false after his or her move.
The player whose order of cucumbers matches the race's outcome best wins the game.

boardgame.name: Splatter: The food fight game
boardgame.description:
The game comes with 48 cards and a set of instructions. The players need six-sided dice and to provide a set of 10 tokens for each player.

Turn Sequence:
1. Discard one cover card
2. Draw one card
3. Perform one action
a. Clean up
b. Attack
c. Draw one card
4. End of Turn

"Clean up": Any number of cards can be discarded to remove 2 "mess points" each.

"Attack": Up to 3 cards can be played for an attack, but no more than 1 "food", 1 "bonus", or 1 "aim" card. The defender may play up to three cards face-down as "cover". If the defender is missed, he or she may make a "smack back attack" which cannot be defended or retaliated against. The game ends when one player accumulates 10 or more "mess points". The game comes with a few very minor alternate rules.

boardgame.name: Allez, on rentre à la maison!
Andiamo a casa
Die Koala Brüder: Auf Geht's Nach Haus!
boardgame.description:
KOALA BROTHERS - LET'S GO HOME is a childrens memory game based on the animated children's television series.

What a mess! The vehicles belonging to the Koala Brothers and their friends are completely mixed up and little by little, as night falls, the way home is hard to find. Where is the scooter? Who knows where Frank and Buster’s house is? Your mission is to help the friends to get themselves and their vehicles back to the right house.

The game is comprised of five small boards representing the homes of the Koala Brothers and their friends. Each house has three spaces on it. The (two) Koala brothers and four of their friends appear on six red counters and their preferred means of transport are represented on five blue counters (the koala brothers fly a twin seater plane).

At the start of the game the counters are mixed up, one of the red ones removed, and the remaining ten distributed at random between the houses.

Players take it in turns to roll a special die and take actions accordingly:

• If it shows a number then the player moves a piece of his choice the number of free spaces indicated on the die. Movement can be in either a clockwise or anticlockwise direction.
• If it shows an eye the player can secretly look at a counter of his/her choice.
• If it shows an arrow the player selects a playing piece of his/her choice and turns it up so that everyone can see.

Players may also gamble tokens by secretly peeking at counters. If the counter is at the right house then it wins tokens, if not it loses tokens.

Play proceeds until all the friends and their vehicles are face up in the right location. The player with the greatest number of tokens is the winner.

boardgame.name: Scrambled Heads!
boardgame.description:
SCRAMBLED HEADS! - The Crazy Clues Game! is a similar game to HEADBANZ and others of that ilk.

Players take it in turns to be the 'Head Case' by placing a headpiece on their head. A card is placed in the headpiece by another player such that it can be seen by all the players except the one actually wearing the headpiece.

The game card shows three subjects in three different categories - Food and Drink, Entertainment and Miscellaneous. The subject is something that should be familiar to all the players and could be anything from a famous film star to a wild animal.

The 'Head Case' selects whether he wishes clues on the category on the top, middle or bottom row of his card, and is then informed of which particular category the subject belongs to.

The other players then take it in turns to offer clues as to what the subject is. Clues should be relevant to the subject but somewhat distant and slightly cryptic. Clues should not be derived from part of the subject title. The 'Head Case' has 10 seconds to try and guess the text on the card at which point the next player gives another clue.

Tokens are added into a central pile to indicate how many clues have been given - these tokens having been evenly distributed amongst the players at the start of the game. If the 'Head Case' guesses the subject then the player that gave the last clue must collect all the tokens. A player also gains them if he is unable to provide a suitable clue. In the event of the 'Head Case' not guessing the answer within 12 clues he fails and collects all the tokens from the pile,

Another player is then selected as the 'Head Case' and the while process is repeated. Play continues until one of the players runs out of tokens or when all players agree to stop.

boardgame.name: UNO H2O Splash
boardgame.description:
This version of UNO includes transparent, waterproof cards similar to UNO H2O and a special Whirlpool device. The Whirlpool has random effects that appear when shook (it works like a Magic 8-Ball).

The rules are simplified. For example, the winner conditions are no longer points based. The first player to win three hands wins the game. Also gone are rules regarding playing Wild Draw 4 Cards when you can play another card.

The Whirlpool is activated by playing a special Splash card or playing a 0 or a 2. The next player must then shake the Whirlpool and follow the results:
1) Draw H2O - draw until they get a blue, 2, 0 or wild card.
2) Wave Right - show a card to the player on the right.
3) Wave Left - show a card to the player on the left.
4) Wipeout - reverse order of play (player who started the Splash must use the whirlpool)

Other possible Whirlpool results are draw, discard and give cards.

The cards and Whirlpool are contained in a sturdy plastic box, with a slide on/off lid.

boardgame.name: Figaro
boardgame.description:
Figaro is a card game where players are trying to earn the shortest road. Each turn, a player plays a card down in front of another player or in front of themselves. The goal is to get the least amount of cards in a round. The player with the most cards in front of them receives the longest road piece, the player with the second most cards in front of them receives the second longest road piece, and so forth. After three rounds, players add up their road pieces and the player with the shortest road wins.

The game is set in the world of Viva il Re! / King Me!, but with totally different mechanics and one rule in common.

boardgame.name: Bedlam
boardgame.description:
Contents:

One spinner, one queen sized sheet.

From the back of the box:

"For best results more than one player is needed.

The object of Bedlam is to maneuver you and your partner into the most compromising positions possible.

To start, each player sits on the Bedlam sheet. Sensuous bedroom attire and a bottle of wine can add pleasure to the game.

Each player takes turns spinning the Bedlam spinner. When the spinner points to one of the four colors the player who spun may move a hand or foot to that color. Knees and elbows may touch the sheet.

If the spinner points to Anything Goes, that player is given complete freedom of movement over the entire Bedlam sheet. This player may position their body any place on the game sheet as long as the other player(s) do not move from their positions. When the player is satisfied with their position, play resumes.

If a player spins Your Request, the player who spun may position the other players on the Bedlam sheet in any position desired as long as they do not move from their position.

When the players have reached compromising positions, Bedlam is declared and you take it from there. Have fun and remember, 'It's not whether you win or lose but Where you play the game'."

Re-implements:

Twister

boardgame.name: Drei Musketiere
Three Musketeers
boardgame.description:
Three Musketeers was first published in Sid Sackson´s A Gamut of Games.

Three Musketeers is played on a 5 x 5 square grid board. The bottom left corner, the center and the top right corner are starting spaces for the three musketeers. All other spaces are initially occupied by "enemies." Musketeers can only move to adjacent spaces with an enemy piece, which is captured by this move. Enemies can only move to empty adjacent spaces. Enemies win if all three musketeers are ever on the same line or column. Musketeers win as soon as they run out of legal moves.

Musketeers will start the game. According to Wikipedia the game was strongly solved in 2009 by Johannes Laire. The enemies (that could be called Cardinal Richelieu's men) can always force a own win. References are missing but due to the restricted amount of available moves for the Musketeers and the strict, clear, and simple rule set proof is possible with acceptable effort with same result.

boardgame.name: ZIN
boardgame.description:
This game is played on a 7x7 square board.The board shows several "win-fields", each depicting two symbols (male and female).

The players take turns drawing a tile from his own stack of tiles. They then place the tile on the board. The tile shows one of three symbols: male, female and mountain. The tile must be played next to a win-field, in such a way that the symbols match (a mountain can be played next to a side that shows both male and female, or neither).

When a win-field is completely surrounded, it is scored. Both players count the tiles they have next to the win-field (tiles are worth one or two points). The player who has the most points scores as many points as his opponents has present.

The game ends when all tiles have been played. At that point, some extra points are distributed and the total score is determined. The player with the most points wins.

Le Secret de Grimbergen (The Secret of Grimbergen) is a deduction game produced for the Grimbergen Abbey Brewery in Belgium. The game is described as being a "Medieval Adventure" and is published in French and Dutch.

From the box:

Walk through the corridors and rooms of Grimbergen Abbey to find the monks that will permit you to discover the secret of the beer that you wish to make. You will need to unite the three monks that each know a part of the secret, in one of the rooms in the Abbey. In order to do this you will need to enter the secret maze, pass through obscure tunnels and battle with your adversaries. Who will be the first to discover the Secret of Grimbergen?

If you have any questions, feel free to send us an email (laden@gamers-hq.de), give us a call (+49 30 79706126) or visit our homepage (www.gamers-hq.de).
Our Terms and Conditions
1. General
All transactions between Gamers HQ and you, the customer, are subject to the following conditions, which you acknowledge by accepting delivery of your ordered products. These conditions do not affect your statutory rights and in all cases German law applies.
2. Orders and prices
We do our level best to ensure that the information on our website is up-to-date. Please note that offers and prices are subject to change. We work to ensure that our prices are all correct, but cannot be held responsible for accidentally displaying the wrong price of a product.
All prices are quoted in Euros and already include all necessary taxes.
3. Lead times and delivery costs
Our products are delivered directly from our Berlin base, and orders are usually dispatched within two working days. Dispatch and transport are at the expense of the customer. We usually ship orders with DHL but explicitly reserve the right to choose another method of transport. If an order is split into several deliveries, each delivery counts as a separate transaction.
Delivery within Germany is free of charge if your order amounts to a total of 50 euros or more. Below that amount, we charge a one-off fee of 5 euros.
Our products can also be ordered for delivery outside Germany. In that case, an estimate of the delivery costs is added to your order during checkout. Please note that this delivery cost estimate does not necessarily constitute the final amount. We shall contact you personally by email after you have placed your order to present you with delivery options and to quote the final price for delivery costs.
4. Payment options
We currently offer the following three payment options: direct debit from your bank account (only within Germany), bank transfer (prepayment) and PayPal. Once you have placed three orders, we also offer you the option to pay by invoice. Such privileges can, however, be withdrawn should we encounter repeated delays in settling invoices.
5. Cancellations, Refunds & Returns Should you wish to cancel your order, you can do so by notifying us by fax, email, letter or by simply returning your product(s) to Gamers HQ. No questions asked. Please note that such a cancellation has to be done within two weeks after having received your ordered product(s). Should you have already paid for your order, we shall refund those costs to you as soon as we have received your cancellation notification. Please ensure that any products returned are in good condition. If you check the products in a manner that you will have done, for example, in a shop, this is fine. Any other handling of the product(s) might entitle Gamers HQ to some compensation from you, which might in rare cases amount to the original sum paid for the product(s). So should you feel that you might cancel your order by returning the products, please limit your inspection of the products to optical checks and do not use them on a regular basis. If you return your order within two weeks in the above manner, we shall refund you the costs for sending the product(s) back to us (unless your cancelled order amounts less than 20 euros, in which case you as the customer will bear the cost of return postage). Please ensure that you use appropriate packing material when sending back the product(s) — preferably using the original wrapping. Please note that German law, following the EU directive 97/7/EG of 20 May 1997, specifies that the right to return items and receive a full refund is not applicable to the purchase of newspapers, magazines or journals (§312d BGB) as well as the purchase of audio- or video-recordings and software once you have broken the seal of the package. Should we accidently send you the wrong products, please return them to us and we shall refund you the return postage immediately. Any cancellation of an order has to be done in writing (by post, fax or email). 6. Ownership
Please note that ordered products remain our property until you have fully paid for them.
7. Personal data
We are committed to protecting your personal information and will keep the information you entrust to us safely and securely. We may collect information from you to monitor website visitor patterns, so that we can improve our website. We also collect information from you to handle orders, deliver products and services, process payments, communicate with you about orders, products and services, update our records and generally maintain your customer profile with us. However, we shall never sell or share your personal information with third parties. Our customer data — in so far as required to provide the above services and within the limits defined by the data protection laws of Germany (paragraph 26 BDSG) — is saved and handled on a separate, network-independent computer.
8. Other matters
We reserve the right to reject orders without any explanation. Also please note that you as a customer cannot assert a claim against Gamers HQ if, for whatever reason, we are unable to source the item(s) you have ordered. Such cases arise only very exceptionally; we try to ensure that everything we advertise in our web shop is in stock. Where, for whatever reason, we are unable to deliver we promptly refund in full everything you have paid.
9. Limitation of liability: external links
Although we check the content of external links provided on our website, we have no control over or responsibility for these domains to which we provide the links or which link to us. That responsibility solely rests with those who manage the respective domains.
10. Place of jurisdiction
Any disputes arising hereunder will be settled before a Berlin court. We reserve the right to choose the customer's place of jurisdiction instead.
11. Severability clause
If parts of these terms and conditions become ineffective, the remainder of these terms still apply.

Yak is a board game for 2 players, which involves a combination of luck and skill. Typical duration of the game is about 15 minutes.

Objectives:
The object of the game is to move your counters across the board whilst your opponent moves their counters across the board in the opposite direction. The winner is the first player to remove off all of their counters.

Equipment:
A long narrow board marked with 16 squares in a single line. There are 16 counters and 4 dice, 8 white counters plus 2 white dice and 8 black counters plus 2 black dice.

boardgame.name: Dicecar
boardgame.description:
From the publisher's web site:

This is Dicecar's Tri-Oval Speedway. Now available with either Dicecar Jr. rules and Extreme Dicecar rules packages.
Here’s the skinny of what Dicecar is. Dicecar is a Table Top Racing game that is played using dice and cards. The drivers must have their own 1/64th scale race cars. These are available at most department stores in the toy section or at your local racing collectible stores. Some spaces on the race track allow you lane changes or prompt you to draw cards which could be good or bad. Pit road is outlined in yellow, so you know where the speed limit begins. Strategies include pit stops in which you choose gas only, one side or both sides tire changes. Avoiding trouble and making moves which can put you in front of the competition are important strategies as well. To win you must be the first driver to cross the start/finish line after completing all of the laps and pit stops. Table Top Racing is no fantasy as you race face to face with your family and friends. Everyone can race at Dicecar. You don’t need to be a race fan to enjoy the game. Racing knowledge can help but it is not necessary. Experience counts, so race a few times as you develop your strategy. Dicecar includes qualifying, drafting, unscheduled pit stops for tire or engine trouble. Crashes can happen and the yellow flag will bring out the pace car for a caution. Have fun racing and building your 1/64th scale racing world. Different tracks are available as well as accessories like the high banks and soft walls. Other items such as the pace car, jet dryer trucks, tow trucks and ambulances are also available and make your world of Dicecar a lot of fun.

boardgame.name: Blue Moon City
Mesto Modrega Meseca
Η Πόλη του Γαλάζιου Φεγγαριού
Город синей луны
boardgame.description:
Blue Moon City - the board game - picks up where the two-player game, (Blue Moon), ended: the reconstruction of the destroyed city of Blue Moon. The board, illustrated by Franz Vohwinkel as well as many well-known American fantasy artists, consists of 21 large building tiles, which show building plans on one side and the buildings in their reconstructed glory on the other. As in the 2-player game, the game includes 3 large molded plastic dragons.

At the start of the game, the board tiles all show their building plan sides. The object of the game is to use cards featuring the races of Blue Moon to help rebuild the city and, at the end, put the large Crystal of the Obelisk in the middle of the city back together. Whenever a building is completely rebuilt, its tile is turned back over to its rebuilt side. The players who helped with a building get crystals and dragon favors, which can be traded in for crystals at certain times.

The player who first manages to add the required number of markers by paying crystals to the Obelisk wins the game. (four markers in a 4-player game, five markers in a 3-player game, and six markers in a 2-player game)

There are two mini-expansions for this game (Blue Moon City: Expansion Tile Sets 1 & 2), each consisting of two tiles that can be added to the main game either separately or combined. The first mini-expansion was included with the Der Knizia Almanach. The second mini-expansion was included in the 6/06 issue of Spielbox.

Rules changes

Original Knizia design--after dragon scales score, ALL players discard scales. This rule was modified by the publisher. [citation needed]
In original printings such as my Kosmos and FFG for 4-3-2 players the game uses 15-12-9 dragon scales. In later edtions new publisher CMON changed this to 12-9-7 scales.

boardgame.name: ConverStation
boardgame.description:
This game was created by a speech pathologist to ensure that conversation doesn't become a lost art. The designer found that children that are not used to adult conversation will often reply to questions with one-word answers or an answer not related to what the question that they were asked. The game is also helpful for adults that have had strokes, brain injuries, or are attempting to relearn or expand their language skills.

As a player lands on certain colored game board squares in a train track format, a player chooses one of 240 question cards, divided into the four corresponding color categories of "Wh- Questions, "If I...", "Tell about...", and "How do you...". The game cards have three levels: kids, adults, and both.

The companion workbook called ConverStation Graphic Expression teaches people when to express themselves in writing versus conversation.

The board game hit the market in June 2005, winning the 2005 Preferred Choice Award from Creative Child magazine as a Toy of the Year Finalist.

The game is published by Say It Right, a small press educational publisher based in Tybee Island, Georgia. Their website is www.sayitright.org.

boardgame.name: Beginning Math Roll & Learn Pocket Cubes
boardgame.description:
Here's an innovative new way to learn Beginning Math skills, plus, as an added bonus, your students will have so much fun they won't realize how much they're learning!

Rather than the same old boring drills, numerous worksheets, or endless practice exercises, introduce your students to an exciting new way of learning with the Roll & Learn Pocket Cubes. The set includes: two pocket cubes made of the same durable material as our pocket charts, 24 learning cards, and a resource guide. The learning cards are designed to slide easily into plastic sleeves that are located on each side of the cube. Each card has either a photograph or colorful text printed on it.

The game instructions vary depending on the skill being taught that day. Some games require both cubes being tossed, while others have students toss one cube and find the correct answer on the remaining cube. The games include: numerals and number sets, shapes, numbers comparisons, as well as simple addition. These games can be played with either the whole class or placed in a learning center for small group or individual play.

This set is a terrific tool for teaching with a kinesthetic approach.

boardgame.name: Augsburg 1520
boardgame.description:
From Alea:

The game is about Jakob Fugger, who was probably the wealthiest man of his time. “Jakob the Rich,” as he was named in his time, owned so much money that he loaned money to a host of counts and kings. Often, they were not able to repay him in cash, so they awarded him special privileges, such as trade rights and offices.

2 to 5 players ages 12 and up assume the role of the merchants from Augsburg and try to get what they can -- by means of auctions -- from the nobility, thus increasing their wealth and particularly their social status.

The game play uses a simple bidding mechanism. Each round, players offer cards of varying values in a series of five auctions. Once a bid is made, players either raise the bid, call, or drop. The winning player may choose from a set of possible actions that increase abilities (and more importantly, points). After a number of rounds (dependent on the number of players), scores are tallied. It's that simple.

This is a game by Karsten Hartwig, whose other game “Chinatown” was already published by Alea. Game length varies -- depending on the number of players -- between 25 to 90 minutes. The difficulty level is a 4 on the Alea 1-10 scale (the same as Ra).

Besides the players’ tableaus and a game board, there are 90 game cards and various game chits.

This game is #3 in the Alea medium box series.

boardgame.name: Flight of the Eagle
Le Vol de l'Aigle
boardgame.description:
Le Vol de l’Aigle (Flight of the Eagle ) is a game simulating Napoleonic era campaigns. It is double- blind based, as the players can communicate with each other only through messages carried by the umpire. It is played on nineteenth century maps from Thier’s atlas with a quite simple system. The players are really acting the part of the general, who barely knew where the enemy, as well as his own army, were. The game needs only paper and pens, with a few dice. It is the first volume of a three-volume series eventually covering all the issues of Napoleonic warfare.

Includes :
- 1806 campaign in Prussia
- 1806-1807 scenarios in Poland : Pultusk, Eylau, Friedland
- 1809 beginning campaign in Bavaria

boardgame.description:
This game is included in a series of books called "Drageherren" ("The Dragon master", an easy-to-read fantasy series by Josefine Ottesen). The basic game comes with the first book in the series and the rest of the books will have small expansions to the game.

The basic game plays a little like the old Titan boardgame, with each player having secret armies on the map. Each player got one treasure hidden in one of his armies, and the goal is to get both of them to Rai (the capital in the middle of the board) and keep them there for 3 turns.

The two players will try to get his armies into the most favorable terrain which is different for each unit. Each army got one leader and two units (hidden at the start of the game) and the combat is simple dice rolling. The board is made in the same way as in Settlers of Catan, and uses hexes with various terrain.

"Kampen om Rai" was published as a "base" set in book 1. Followed by 10 sequels with 10 expansions total.

boardgame.name: Pitwits
boardgame.description:
The quick-witted game for for quick-witted people!

Pitwits challenges you to think fast, but think straight. You all take a turn to read a set of five clues to the others, the clues get easier as more are read. You simply shout out the answer when you think you know it; if correct all the others move down the board towards the pit and out of the game, if wrong then you move towards the pit.

Movement is related to the number of clues which have been read before the answer is given - the more clues, the less movement - e.g. 1 clue = 5 spaces, 5 clues = 1 space.

The last player left in the game wins.

boardgame.name: Leonardo da Vinci
Maestro Leonardo
列奥纳多·达芬奇
達文西
레오나르도 다빈치
boardgame.description:
Theme:
Florence, fifteenth century. The inventors of the Renaissance created amazing machines for the Lord of the city. Become the protagonist of this age of unbelievable discoveries by realizing your inventions! You'll direct your team into the laboratories, workshops, among the shops and perhaps learn the intrigues of the palace. Only the best can rival the great Leonardo!

Summary:
A worker-placement game for 2-5 players with an interesting bidding mechanic. In many other worker-placement games, if an opponent beats you to a spot, you're out of luck. Not so in Leonardo de Vinci. Here, you can bid more workers to jump ahead in line. And people at the back of the line, can still get something, but they have to pay more to get it. The competition for resources is very dynamic and fun.

Your same workers that compete for resources may also power your laboratory, so you must balance acquiring resources with working in the laboratory so that you can complete inventions and not run out of Florins (i.e. manage cash-flow).

The key is planning your resources and production capacity to maximize the number of inventions you can make and therefore maximize the amount of Florins you can earn. The last two rounds of the game require extra careful planning because new resources cannot be acquired.

Meta:
A "gamers' game" by Acchittocca (a team of Italian game designers). Nr. 1 in the QWG Master Print Edition series

All games are new and in their original wrapping and all prices include the German VAT (7% or 19%).
We offer only goods that we have in stock.
We ship worldwide – please ask for a quote about exact shipping costs (rest assured that we always try to keep them as low as possible).
Payment may be made by Paypal or bank transfer in advance.
For orders above €50 we grant a discount of €5 on shipping costs.
If you have any questions, feel free to send us an email (laden@gamers-hq.de), give us a call (+49 30 79706126) or visit our homepage (www.gamers-hq.de).
Our Terms and Conditions
1. General
All transactions between Gamers HQ and you, the customer, are subject to the following conditions, which you acknowledge by accepting delivery of your ordered products. These conditions do not affect your statutory rights and in all cases German law applies.
2. Orders and prices
We do our level best to ensure that the information on our website is up-to-date. Please note that offers and prices are subject to change. We work to ensure that our prices are all correct, but cannot be held responsible for accidentally displaying the wrong price of a product.
All prices are quoted in Euros and already include all necessary taxes.
3. Lead times and delivery costs
Our products are delivered directly from our Berlin base, and orders are usually dispatched within two working days. Dispatch and transport are at the expense of the customer. We usually ship orders with DHL but explicitly reserve the right to choose another method of transport. If an order is split into several deliveries, each delivery counts as a separate transaction.
Delivery within Germany is free of charge if your order amounts to a total of 50 euros or more. Below that amount, we charge a one-off fee of 5 euros.
Our products can also be ordered for delivery outside Germany. In that case, an estimate of the delivery costs is added to your order during checkout. Please note that this delivery cost estimate does not necessarily constitute the final amount. We shall contact you personally by email after you have placed your order to present you with delivery options and to quote the final price for delivery costs.
4. Payment options
We currently offer the following three payment options: direct debit from your bank account (only within Germany), bank transfer (prepayment) and PayPal. Once you have placed three orders, we also offer you the option to pay by invoice. Such privileges can, however, be withdrawn should we encounter repeated delays in settling invoices.
5. Cancellations, Refunds & Returns Should you wish to cancel your order, you can do so by notifying us by fax, email, letter or by simply returning your product(s) to Gamers HQ. No questions asked. Please note that such a cancellation has to be done within two weeks after having received your ordered product(s). Should you have already paid for your order, we shall refund those costs to you as soon as we have received your cancellation notification. Please ensure that any products returned are in good condition. If you check the products in a manner that you will have done, for example, in a shop, this is fine. Any other handling of the product(s) might entitle Gamers HQ to some compensation from you, which might in rare cases amount to the original sum paid for the product(s). So should you feel that you might cancel your order by returning the products, please limit your inspection of the products to optical checks and do not use them on a regular basis. If you return your order within two weeks in the above manner, we shall refund you the costs for sending the product(s) back to us (unless your cancelled order amounts less than 20 euros, in which case you as the customer will bear the cost of return postage). Please ensure that you use appropriate packing material when sending back the product(s) — preferably using the original wrapping. Please note that German law, following the EU directive 97/7/EG of 20 May 1997, specifies that the right to return items and receive a full refund is not applicable to the purchase of newspapers, magazines or journals (§312d BGB) as well as the purchase of audio- or video-recordings and software once you have broken the seal of the package. Should we accidently send you the wrong products, please return them to us and we shall refund you the return postage immediately. Any cancellation of an order has to be done in writing (by post, fax or email). 6. Ownership
Please note that ordered products remain our property until you have fully paid for them.
7. Personal data
We are committed to protecting your personal information and will keep the information you entrust to us safely and securely. We may collect information from you to monitor website visitor patterns, so that we can improve our website. We also collect information from you to handle orders, deliver products and services, process payments, communicate with you about orders, products and services, update our records and generally maintain your customer profile with us. However, we shall never sell or share your personal information with third parties. Our customer data — in so far as required to provide the above services and within the limits defined by the data protection laws of Germany (paragraph 26 BDSG) — is saved and handled on a separate, network-independent computer.
8. Other matters
We reserve the right to reject orders without any explanation. Also please note that you as a customer cannot assert a claim against Gamers HQ if, for whatever reason, we are unable to source the item(s) you have ordered. Such cases arise only very exceptionally; we try to ensure that everything we advertise in our web shop is in stock. Where, for whatever reason, we are unable to deliver we promptly refund in full everything you have paid.
9. Limitation of liability: external links
Although we check the content of external links provided on our website, we have no control over or responsibility for these domains to which we provide the links or which link to us. That responsibility solely rests with those who manage the respective domains.
10. Place of jurisdiction
Any disputes arising hereunder will be settled before a Berlin court. We reserve the right to choose the customer's place of jurisdiction instead.
11. Severability clause
If parts of these terms and conditions become ineffective, the remainder of these terms still apply.

boardgame.name: Colour Magic
boardgame.description:
Colour Magic

From the makers of Math Magic™ and Math Magic 2™ comes a new challenge as a puzzle for a single player or a game for two players. Colour Magic relies on your power of deduction to place your tiles on the board so they do not cover any of a designated color. The player who places the most tiles wins. Sounds simple? This game will challenge all who love games of logic and strategy. Great for travel! Contains small parts, not suitable for children under the age of four.

boardgame.name: Buster Brown and the Goat
boardgame.description:
A card game featuring Buster Brown, Tige, and friends similar to Old Maid. The Goat is the odd card or the "Old Maid" that you don't want to be caught with or you lose the game!

Rules from the game box:
Deal 3 cards to each player and 3 to the table face up. If the Goat is dealt to the table, he must be put back in the pack shuffled, and a new card dealt to the table in its place.

The first player must make a pair by matching a card on the table with one in his hand if he can, at the same time reading aloud the title of the card, for instance, "I am Buster's Father". He then takes the trick to himself. If he cannot make a pair in that way, then he must play a card on the table, any one he likes, except for the Goat.

After his play, he must then take the top card from the pack, so that he will always hold 3 cards, until the pack runs out, when there are no more cards to draw from. Then, if a player cannot make a pair by matching one on the table, he may make one from his hand. If he can do neither, he must draw a card from his left-hand neighbor and try to make a pair from the table or from his hand, and so on, until the last card remains unplayed which must be the Goat. The player with that card must hold it up and say "I am the Goat."

boardgame.name: Friendzee: Christian Character Edition
boardgame.description:
Players move game pieces around the Friendzee game board by rolling cubes that direct them to draw from three sets of cards:
1) LIVE OUT LOUD--surprising and meaningful experiences challenge participants to tell stories, sculpt clay, write, sketch, perform charades...and more.
2) DIVE IN DEEP--gets them digging into Bible passages and studying God's Word together on a more personal level.
3) RISKZEE--a roll of the dice directs players to do both wacky and Bible-themed activities as they explore Scripture.
All three cards guide teens around the game board and to the ENDZEE. There are no winners and no losers--the game ends when everyone reaches the ENDZEE and commits to a challenge for the week.

The Christian Character Edition encourages teen to deepen their faith by discussing Courage, Integrity, Humility, Grace, Compassion, and Perseverance.

boardgame.name: XIG 4E: Air Pathway
boardgame.description:
XIG is a tile-laying game where players try to be the first to complete their own pathway - based on one of four elements: Earth, Water, Fire, and Air - as quickly as possible by laying down puzzle-piece style tiles. There are also cards that can help you advance or hinder your opponent. The pathways are sold in complete sets, and booster packs of cards are currently planned.

The base game includes the Water and Earth pathways. This is one of the first two expansions for the game (the other being the Fire pathway). It includes the entire Air pathway, a set of XAG cards, a small "collector's" box, and 2 special bonus "new edition" XAG cards plus 1 special "limited edition" foil puzzle piece. Other future expansions are hinted at in the rules.

Expands:

XIG: The Four Elements

boardgame.name: Barnum's Animals Crackers Game
boardgame.description:
An over-sized animal crackers box (complete with string handle) containing 16 animal cards, 9 plastic animal crackers/cookies and a cloth bag to put them in.

The rules describe three games to be played with these components, all of which are memory/matching games:

1) One card is placed face down for each animal in the bag. Players draw an animal from the bag and then attempt to flip over the corresponding card. Success allows the player to retain the card and animal cracker, while failure requires the player to return the cracker to the bag and flip the card back over.

2) As above, but two cards are placed for each animal and players must attempt to match the drawn cracker with both matching cards.

3) All cards are placed face-down in a stack. Players draw a card from the stack and then attempt to retrieve the matching animal cracker from the bag by feel (without looking). Success allows the player to keep the matching set, while failure requires that the animal be returned to the bag.

In all cases, the winner is the player with the most card/cracker sets.

Best played while nibbling on Barnum's Animals Crackers.

boardgame.name: The New and Fashionable Game of the Jew
boardgame.description:
Cloth-backed, hand-colored folding engraving with slip cover. Shows a publication date of May 27th, 1807. Board is 18.5 x 16", cover is 7 x 5".

Game is played with two six-sided dice, but while I have pictures of the case and board, I can find no explantion of game play other than this quote from "Deconstructing Sondheim", a March 8, 1993 New Yorker article by Stephen Schiff:

When you enter his five-story town house in midtown Manhattan, the first thing you notice, besides an enormous black poodle named Max, is his antique-game collection: on the walls, in glass museum cases, on various low tables. Most of the items look faintly sinister: here is something called Schimmel, or Ball and Hammer and here an inscrutable British concoction, Squails, and, behind the sofa, his earliest acquisition—the ghastly New and Fashionable Game of the Jew, a dice game devised in 1811 that, according to Sondheim, "taught kids to be anti-Semitic. But all the games you see here are very nice to look at and real boring," he adds. "This thing about games—I'm not really fascinated with games."

--
Looks to be a variation of Gluckshaus. Roll both dice and pay the amount rolled onto the space of the same value. If there is something already on the space, collect it instead. Rolling a 7 always pays to the Jew space. Rolling a 12 collects all the counters on the board.
From: http://www.gamesetal.net/Stock_Pages/GLB/glb3930.htm

boardgame.description:
The title derives from a German phrase, meaning something ordinary. (Originally it came from a machine gun, used a lot in World War I, and was made popular because of a bestselling war novel and film of this title.) The game however is an abstract speed game. It consists of 108 cards in 9 colours, denoted "0", "8" or "15". Goal for each player is to collect the most card sets in one colour, consisting of one card of each number.

Decks of each number are separated. "0" and "15" are each shuffled, and put as two face up stack on the table. "8" cards are shared evenly among players, and put as face down stacks in front of them. Determined by numbers of players, a given number of "8" cards are revealed from each players deck, and everybody tries to match the two face up cards from the common decks with their tableau. If they find the "0" matching to one of their "8", they put it below their card. A matching "15" they put on top of their "8". Once a set is complete, it is removed into a victory point pile and another "8" from the players deck takes it place. Game ends, as soon the decks are depleted.

boardgame.name: Checkered Flag
boardgame.description:
Checkered Flag is similar in nature to Formula-1 and Speed Circuit. Players choose their cars speed on a dashboard and move one space for every 20 miles per hour. The same dashboard is used to track fuel usage, tire wear and brake wear. Players also have a small hand of five cards that provide certain benefits when played. Unlike the other two games, Checkered Flag simulates stock car racing.

Given that speeds are more constant in stock car racing, there are only three speed choices; 60, 120 and 180 miles per hour. At the beginning of the race and after a pit stop, cars start off at 60. In the two turns, the maximum speed is 120. The turns drive the primary choices available, as some lanes provide a shorter path than others. The choice lanes have a cost in fuel usage or tire wear. The first car to complete three laps wins the race.

boardgame.name: Hank Aaron Baseball Game
Sure Shot Baseball
boardgame.description:
Various versions of this game have existed for many years. I am not sure if this game has been renamed?

Sure Shot Baseball is a two person game played much the same way as outdoor baseball. The game consists of nine innings of 3 outs each. The "pitcher" rolls a plastic marble down a slide and it heads toward a batter controlled by their opponent. The "batter" tries to hit the ball out of the stadium by turning a batting knob. If it goes out of the unique up-curved field the "fielder" then tries to catch it. Singles, doubles, triples, foul balls, and home runs are determined where the ball goes over the wall. The "runners" stay in their team dugouts until it is time to position them on the field.

Each "batter" gets only one pitch. A missed pitch counts as one out. Each team gets three outs and then players change positions. Players play nine innings and whomever has the most runs wins.

There are a few other simple rules. The game is quite tricky to learn and play competitively. But it is definitely a fun experience if you enjoy baseball!!

boardgame.name: High 5
boardgame.description:
"High 5" is a party game that, like the more popular "Cranium" which it pre-dates, combines five party-style games into one.

Players (or teams) roll four 10-sided dice to generate a four-digit number that corresponds to a question in "The Book of 10,000 Questions." The number also indicates which of the five categories of game type the player will have. The categories are: "Pic-Wit" (Pictionary) "Bull-Wit" (Balderdash) "Ham-Wit" (Charades) "Sher-Wit" (20 Questions) and "Wiz-Wit" (Trivia).

The question book indicates how many spaces the players advance. In some situations, both the players asking the questions and the players responding will be able to advance. In other situations, an incorrect answer will send a player backwards along the track.

Questions for younger players are included in the question book, allowing players to create an easier game for children.

boardgame.name: RAN
乱
boardgame.description:
(from GMT website:)

RAN is the 12th volume in the "Great Battles of History" Series, and the second game on the battles of the Samurai (following GMTs Samurai (Vol. V). RAN covers several of the less famous of the Sengoku Jidai, the Age of Warring States (more or less), in which powerful Daimyo - Japanese feudal lords - strove to both maintain and extend their power bases while seeking to attain the office of Shogun, the power behind the throne of the Emperor.

RAN simulates the highly personal form of warfare developed by the Japanese samurai, wherein formal battles played out almost as backdrops to individual feats of courage, bravery and devotion much of it outstanding, some of it rather foolhardy, all of it very Homeric. Although political and tactical victory was the bottom line, collecting the severed heads of enemy samurai reigned a very close second in importance. In terms of tactics, this was, as in Europe, the Dawn of Modern Warfare, with the introduction of guns - arquebuses - by the Portuguese. Even with the revelatory effect of musketry, Japanese battles were still pretty much a swirling, non-linear affair.

RAN, the name the famous Japanese film director, Kurosawa, chose for his samurai version of King Lear, roughly means “Chaos.”

The Battles of RAN (all battles are one-half map, except for Tennoji):


MIMASETOGE (6 October 1569): The Takeda are trying to return to their castle base, and the Hojo are trying to intercept and ambush them with twice their number. A startling Takeda victory.



MIMIGAWA (11 November 1578) Interrupted while besieging Takajpo Castle, the Otomi retreat into the woods, then burst out to attack the Shimazu relief force, only to be outwitted by clever Shimazu tactics.



NAGAKUTE (17 May 1582): Tokugawa vs Ikeda, in a nice, small battle (less than 10,000 men each). Set piece affair fought over very difficult terrain … mountains, rice paddies, etc.



NUNOBEYAMA (14 February 1570): The Amako vs The Mori



OKITANAWATE (24 March 1584): The Ryuzoji vs The Shimazu



SURIAGEHARA (5 June 1589): Date Masamune (and his 23,000 men) hold off an initially effective attack by Asahina Yosohiro's 16,000 man army on relatively flat terrain. Key use of reserves.



TENNOJI (7 May 1615): One of the biggest battles of the era (and the only full map battle in the box). After Sekigahara, Hideyori, son of Hideysohi, challenges Tokugawa... the result is a battle with over 250,000 men and a swirling affair with lots of arriving reinforcements.


COMPONENTS

5 Countersheets
2 22 x 33 battle maps, backprinted
1 Battle Rules Book
1 Battle Scenario Book
5 Charts & Tables Cards
2 Record sheets
1 ten-sided die


DESIGNERS: Mark Herman and Richard Berg
ART DIRECTOR: Rodger B. MacGowan
MAP ART: Leland Myrick

Once the six pieces are on the board, play continues in sequential fashion, with each move exposing the now-vacated square to the opponent. The action ends only when the first player achieves a three-in-a-row combination. With this game there is never a tie.

boardgame.name: Gnaqush
boardgame.description:
It’s not just the nickname of the game’s designer – it’s what you’ll do with your teeth as your carefully-laid plans get thwarted and blocked over and over again in this strategic Icehouse game for 4 players.

Original game design and concept by Nash, with additional modifications and variants by The Monday Night Games Group.

Object: Promote your one-pip pieces up to two-pip pieces, then three-pip pieces – eventually promoting the three-pip pieces to Nirvana. The first player with all pieces in Nirvana wins.

You Need

* One Icehouse stash for each player. Each player must have a different color.
* A chessboard.
* (optional) – 16 blocker tokens to fill spaces to modify the board for two or three players.

Normal Play: On your turn you can Jump over an adjacent piece or Slide (Move) one of your valid pieces Move to an adjacent square. When you move a piece or stack into a space occupied by another piece or a stack of pieces, you must cap that stack with the piece(s) you moved.

Ascension: If one or more of your pieces is in your goal square at the end of any turn and your home square is vacant, you must remove one of your pieces from your home square. Set it on its side in front of you, off the board. Put a piece that’s one pip larger point up in your home square. If the piece you removed was a three-pip piece, it has ascended to Nirvana – do not put a piece in your home square.

Winning: If you’re the first player to send your last three-pip piece to Nirvana, the game ends and you win.

Download the full rules plus variants to the rules here:
http://www.invisible-city.com/play/271/gnaqush

boardgame.name: Pericles
Perikles
boardgame.description:
Perikles is a game from Martin Wallace. Players assume the role of a noble family seeking to become the leader of one or more of 6 ancient Greek city-states. The game plays out in two phases:

In the first, players vie for area control in each of the six states, which end in elections. Players who win the election in each state can then "control" that state's army.

In the second phase, players use cards to move their armies to attack or defend one of seven battles (each tied to a state, and you can't attack your own!) that are up for grabs that round.

The gameplay mechanic is straightforward, with elements drawn from other Euro-style wargames (especially Martin Wallace's Struggle of Empires). What makes Perikles unique is the smooth integration of the area control/voting phase and the military phase.

From the back of the box:

"Together the Greek City States had defeated the greatest power in the world, the Persians. Now, though, pride and envy have led them to fight amongst themselves in what we know today as the Peloponnesian War.

Each player represents a powerful Greek family with political influence spread across the six major city states of ancient Greece. Players strive to become leaders of these cities, thus taking control of their military forces. With these forces players will aim to win glory on the battlefield."

boardgame.name: Bitter Victory
boardgame.description:
A game of the Allied invasion of Sicily, 1943.


(from the publisher:)

Most of the rules and mechanics will be familiar to anyone who has ever played a wargame. BSO, however, has added to this simplicity a combat system that rates units for how many dice they get to roll on their behalf, as well as what kind of dice (small arms or heavy weapons). No CRTs, no siree!

The game also uses cards, one deck (of 10) for each player (whose cards are somewhat different from those of the other player) to enhance the game. (They don’t 'drive' the game and they can be left out, if you’re so inclined.) The cards are turned into a Resource system that gives the players a number of points which they can use to buy cards or rally units. The choice is theirs, but there are far more choices than points.

The cards, themselves, give the players 'Opportunities', from using their Tank capabilities, to getting more supplies, to special Reaction movement, to appearances by Patton and Monty.

Playing time for BITTER VICTORY has averaged 3 hours, sometimes less, and the rules are only 8 pages, including a section on Solitaire play!

Available in English or French

Components:

1 rules and scenario booklet with historical introduction (8 pages)
1 A1 map of Sicily
20 colored Opportunity Cards
224 counters (NATO Symbols)
1 Aid Cards


The Sicily map and the Opportunity Cards have been designed by Pascal Da Silva.

boardgame.name: Anastasia
boardgame.description:
Also referred to as Rasputin's Revenge. This game was premium giveaway item to customers of Shell service stations to promote Twentieth Century Fox Film's theatrical release of their animated film, Anastasia. The game comes with the board folded into a triangular suitcase that holds plastic playing pieces of the movie's five main characters and a sheet that folds into a 6-sided die.

The object of the game is for players to safely arrive in Paris and defeat the evil Rasputin. They accomplish this by rolling the die to move ahead the indicated number of spaces. Players must then follow the directions on the space, if provided. To win, players must reach the last space and then be the first to make the correct die roll to destroy Rasputin.

boardgame.name: Age of Battles: Sekigahara 1600
boardgame.description:
Sekigahara 1600 is part of the Age Of Battles table-top miniatures gaming system using 1/72 scale miniatures and the Shogun rule set. Sekigahara 1600 allows you to play the battle over four scenarios:

1. First Clashes
2. Red Devils Attack
3. Kobayakawa Choice
4. Shimadzu Clan Breakthrough

The boxed game set includes everything needed to play out Sekigahara 1600:

88 Samurai Infantry - tan/grey (two sets of ZV 8017)
51 Samurai Cavalry - tan/grey/red (three sets of ZV 8025)
20 Regiment Stands
12 Modular Plastic Trees w/stands
16 Laminated Regiment Cards
1 Pen
2 Rulers
1 Angle Pattern
1 Shogun Rule Book
1 Historical Description Booklet w/battle scenarios and unit tables

From the back of the box:
The military historical game "The Battle of Sakigahara" is based on the fight that took place in the plain near a Japanese village called Sakigahara. Here October 21, 1600 two samurai armies, more than 80,000 people each, met in the bloody battle. Tokugava Leyasu, an experienced general and politician, profited from the treason in the ranks of the enemy and defeated its troops thus stopping endless wars and establishing his shogunate in Japan.

This game is for 2-6 players. The enemy armies led by the players meet in the plain between mountains. Tactic maneuverings are very important in the game. Under a skillful leader a smaller army can defeat an outnumbering enemy. You can either recreate the historic battle or change the course of the fight. Anyway you should rely not only on the number of your army but also on your leadership and war skills.

Zvezda 8207

boardgame.name: Brainbenders
Mindbenders
boardgame.description:
From the box -
First: Read a question
Second: cogitate, digest and discuss
Third: start to pull your hair out, the logical seems illogical, the question seems to have no answer.
Finally: supply an answer or admit defeat

boardgame.name: Pyramid (Battlestar Galactica)
Triad (Battlestar Galactica)
boardgame.description:
Pyramid (Battlestar Galactica) is a card game based on the 1970s television series "Battlestar Galactica". It was depicted as leisure activity for the characters in the television show. Later on, rules and decks of pyramid playing cards were made available commercially to fans of the show. Both are currently out of print.
The game uses a 55 count deck of hexagonal cards separated into three kinds of suits and three ranks as well as a 'capstone' card which is used as a wild card. The game is played very similarly to poker. Players are dealt hands and place bets based on how strong their hand is. There is a discard between bets and players reveal their hands to determine the winner of that round.

Winning hands are determined by a number of factors including suit, rank and matching sets. There are approximately fourteen different hand combinations possible in the game. There is no 'end' to the game, players merely quit at their leisure.

The deck consists of 55 hexagonal cards, which is divided into 3 suits: purple, green and orange. Purple ranks highest and orange ranks lowers. The deck also contains a Capstone (*).

Each suit contains:
- 3 First level cards
- 6 Second level cards
- 9 Third level cards

How To Play
Each player is dealt 6 cards. If a player feels a better hand is possible, he may discard up to 4 cards and receive replacements from the dealer. This may only be done once per hand, much the same as "Draw Poker". Players then construct their best possible pyramid and compare to the other player hands to determine the winner.
Ranks of Hands
A pyramid is made up of at least three cards.

1. First level pyramid consist of 2 third level, and 1 second level card.

2. Second level pyramid consist of 3 third level, and 2 second level card.

3. Third level pyramid consist of 3 third level, 2 second level cards, and 1 first level card.

4. Any of the above may be considered "perfect" when all of the cards used are of the same color. ("Perfect" pyramids rank higher than non-perfect pyramids.)

5. If two or more perfect pyramids are the same level, then the highest suit would win. (NOTE: Only perfect pyramids can be ranked by suit; non-perfect pyramids are considered to have no suit.)

6. If two or more pyramids are still equal, then the persons play another hand to decide the winner.


) The Capstone can be used in place of the first level card in a Perfect third level pyramid. This is the highest of ALL PYRAMIDS!



) The Capstone may also be used as a wild card to replace any card in any pyramid.

boardgame.name: Prompt
boardgame.description:
Taken from the back of the box:

"Played with gloriously illustrated Character and Prompt cards and a variety of quotations from Shakespeare."

This is a light game of memory and card collection requiring a familiarity with Shakespeare's plays. It is best suited to play after a dinner party. Match Prompt and Character cards to your Quotation cards to create sets. The first to match all their cards into sets wins. There are 30 sets.

There are two levels of difficulty, which give different methods of play.

The easy method requires players to complete a Shakespeare quote by filling in the missing word(s) on a Quote card, from a Prompt card and matching them to a Character card. The mechanics of acquiring cards is similar to the children's card game Go Fish.

In the advanced game the mechanics are similar to Happy Families but a good knowledge of Shakespeare is required to get you the cards you desire. If attempting to obtain a Quote card from another player one has to recite the quote in full and be "Dead Letter Perfect".

In both types of game the mechanics may well be based on children's games, but it is unlikely to appeal to children due to the subject matter.

boardgame.name: Set Point Singles and Doubles
boardgame.description:
"The only tennis strategy game that plays like the real thing!"

A tennis simulation game, with different boards, but similar mechanics, for playing singles and doubles. The game is played on a board with 81 boxes on each side of the net, grouped in 9 sections. When you play a shot, you call the section (1-9) that you are aiming at, and then roll 2 D6 to see which box in that area it lands in (1, 12 = fault, 2-11 - numbered sectors). If the box is next to a line, 2D6 are rolled to see if the ball is called out. Players can only play a shot if they can move to the ball to play it. The number of boxes that you can move depends on the type of shot played by your opponent (volley, power shot, lob), and where on the court you are. You also can move some boxes after your shot to set for the next one.

The rules do not specify what length of game, etc., to play. Presumably you would decide to play a set, or a tiebreak, or whatever, and use tennis scoring to decide who won.

boardgame.description:
From the box:
"A Game designed especially for children to play with their grandparents!"

From the instruction sheet:
"Make your way over the river and through the woods. If you are the first player to reach Grandma's House, you win!"

In this game for children age 3 and up, players take turns drawing cards then following the instructions on the cards to move their cars forward along the board to Grandma's House. Cards consist of two types:

Color/shape cards - Move the car forward to the first space matching the color and shape on the card.

Word cards - Kids draw the card, an adult reads it aloud, then the kid follows the instruction or answers the question on the card (things like smile or give another player a hug or answer "What's your middle name?", "Who's your best friend?", etc.) The card then instructs the player to move the car or draw another card.

The first player to reach the end of the board (Grandma's House) wins.

boardgame.name: Giro Galoppo
boardgame.description: Giro Galoppo is a horse racing game driven by cards for players 6 years and up. Its mechanic is similar to "Ave Caesar". First, players take turns placing obstacles (jumps). All players receive an identical set of card with values 1-6. Each turn the players simultaneously select one of their cards and show it. The player with the lowest value (and for ties, farther back), moves first. If your horse and rider land on another player's figure, you displace them backward. If your figure's movement would land you on an obstacle, you lose your turn. First & farthest across the finish line wins.

boardgame.description:
Here is a description of the game from the publisher:

Children Ages 4 and up can feel and form while playing Ramba Samba. Here, players develop their tactile abilities while playing the game. The friendly caterpillar has lots of colorful dresses in her sack, just right for the big carnival. Sadly, Ramba can't remember any more which clothing articles fit which parts of her long body. In Ramba Samba, the name of the game is shapes, feel and a happy little caterpillar with clothes made of lots of colorful wooden pieces.

Each turn, the players simultaneously reach into the bag to find the next matching puzzle piece. The winner is the player who places the most pieces.

Ramba Samba demands tactile awareness in a fun-filled way. Because only the player who can feel the matching pieces fastest will win.

boardgame.name: Doctor Key-Bit
Doktor Klucznik
Doktor Schlüsselbart
boardgame.description:
DOCTOR KEY-BIT is proof that even the best magic is nothing compared to good intuition. Doctor Key-Bit, the famous doctor of alchemy, comes home from his meeting of magical doctors and finds out that he has locked the doors to his enchanted castle by magic spell. But now he has forgotten the magic spell to reopen them.

Players try to move Doctor Key-Bit on the game board from one room to another. They’ll need good intuition, because they search through their bags – which are filled with different keys – for a key that fits. Each player moves Doctor Key-Bit to one of four different elixir bottles that are located in the rooms on the game board. Since each player looks for different elixirs, you’ll need a perfect sense of touch to be successful.

The first to move Doctor Key-Bit to four elixirs wins the game and helps the magician to prepare his potion for opening the doors.

DOCTOR KEY-BIT trains the intuition, helps you become quick on the uptake, and teaches you to recognize extraordinary shapes.

boardgame.name: Flivver Game
boardgame.description:
The game box is 6 1/4" by 4 1/4" and 1" deep.

The box contains:

Four die cast touring cars
A spinning wheel board (to generate random movement number)
A one page rulebook.

The game is about racing in Ford "Flivver" (Model T?) cars.

The game is played by spinning the "rear wheel of the Ford indicator" and moving the indicated number of spaces. Text on various spaces affect the players moves. First player to reach home by exact count wins.

NOTE: No car may pass another on the Narrow Road sections of the board, and only one car may occupy a space in these sections. Two players may occupy a space on the rest of the board, but if a third player's spin takes him to the same space he loses his turn. If a spin takes a player to the space marked "spin front wheel" he is entitled to spin the front wheel of the Ford indicator. If this spin lands on the "5", he can move 5 spaces. If it lands on any of the blank spaces, his turn ends.

boardgame.name: Lightning Reaction Extreme
Lightning Reaction Xtreme
boardgame.description:
The game consists of four handles, each equipped with a button. Each player grabs a handle and the game is started. A red light starts to blink and a nasty wailing sound is played. Then, suddenly, the light will turn green and sound goes silent. At that point, players must push the button in their handle. The last player to do that gets an electrical shock. Players will also be shocked if they push the button while the light is still red.

Lightning Reaction Extreme also includes an option to switch to "Extreme" mode. In this mode ONLY the fastest button pusher is safe, while the rest are shocked. In the original only the slowest is shocked. Obviously this only makes a difference with 3 or 4 players. With 2, it plays identical to the original.

The game uses three AAA batteries, so the shock isn't dangerous but it certainly adds an element of tension to the otherwise rather simple test of reacting speed.

Re-implements:

Lightning Reaction
Lightning Reaction Revenge

listing.notes:
Spieleranzahl: 2 bis 2 Spieldauer: 30 Minuten Altersempfehlung: 9+
KARO - Drei Strategiespiele Ein ungewöhnliches Strategiespiel! 24 schwarze quadratische Holzplatten und 16 rote und weiße Spielsteine - das Spiel-material von KARO ist einfach, handlich und ein ästhetisches Vergnügen. Und es bietet eine Vielzahl an Spielmöglichkeiten! Die Platten lassen sich zu immer neuen Spielfeldern zusammensetzen. Die Steine können - dank ihrer besonderen Form und Markierung - vielseitig eingesetzt werden. Das veränderbare Spielfeld und die wandlungsfähigen Spielsteine sind das besondere Merkmal der KARO–Strategiespiele.
Vier Kreise Vier in einer Reihe - ein alter Hut? Die erste der drei Spielvarianten zeigt, was man aus diesem alten Hut zaubern kann. Nicht nur viermal die eigene Farbe ist gefordert, auch die kreisförmige Markierung der Steine will beachtet sein. Sie verschwindet allerdings ebenso schnell, wie sie auftaucht - ein Sprung genügt. Und auch das Spielfeld verändert ständig seine Form. Ein Grund zur Freude (oder Schadenfreude) jedesmal, wenn eine der Platten ihren Platz wechselt. Vier in einer Reihe - ein neues Abenteuer!
Schleicher & Hüpfer Im zweiten KARO-Spiel werden die Platten zu einer Straße.Die Spieler laufen aufeinander zu und um die Wette. Wer ist am schnellsten auf der anderen Seite? Klar, der mit seinen Hüpfern die weitesten Sprünge macht! Doch wird nach jedem Sprung aus dem Hüpfer ein Schleicher, der erst im Schneckentempo Kraft sammeln muss, bevor er wieder springen kann. Man muss eben zum richtigen Zeitpunkt an der richtigen Stelle auf dem Sprung sein!
Erleuchtung - Ein neues Spielfeld – ein neuer Wettlauf! In vier Gruppen stehen die Spielsteine am Rand des Feldes aufgereiht, das in der Mitte ein "Loch" aufweist. Natürlich hat diese Leerstelle eine besondere Bedeutung: Es ist der "Brunnen der Erleuchtung". Jeder Stein der die Mitte betritt, darf umgedreht werden, die Kreismarkierung die dabei auftaucht, gilt als Zeichen seiner "Erleuchtung". Erleuchtung ist außerdem ansteckend: Jeder Stein, der über einen bereits Erleuchteten springt, darf ebenfalls umgedreht werden. Wer als Erster mit allen seinen umgedrehten Steinen wieder am Spielfeldrand steht, hat gewonnen.
Inhalt: 24 Holzplatten 16 Holzspielsteine Spielanleitung
Auszeichnung: Spiel Gut
Mit Spielregeln in folgenden Sprachen: DE, EN, FR

boardgame.name: Die! Die! Bang!
大大阪
boardgame.description:
Each player is one of five Alliances (a criminal organization) and undertakes various crimes in order to receive a reward.

Each player has a scoreboard (which records their 'crime', 'information', 'battle' and 'reward'), Alliance card and Karma table. A Boss is selected (the player with the most criminal convictions!). The Boss selects three Karma cards, takes one and passes two to the player on the left. The process is repeated until all players have two cards. All players roll the dice and place a mission card in the corresponding numbered area.

Players place Alliance cards next to the missions they select. Where more than one player attempts a mission they simultaneously show a thumbs up/thumbs down sign to declare whether they will co-operate or fight. If players co-operate they divide the reward. If players fight they divide into the groups, all who voted to co-operate (if any) are one group, fighters become separate groups of one. Battles are determines by dice roll plus Battle influence. The winner takes the reward. The first player to collect ten rewards wins the game.

boardgame.name: A Bloody Business: The Battle of Hue, 1968
boardgame.description:
(From the game rules:)

A Bloody Business: the Battle for Hue, Tet 1968 covers the attack on the old Imperial capital of Hue by forces of the North Vietnamese Army and South Vietnamese insurgents of the National Liberation Front during the Tet Offensive. The Communist forces hoped a popular uprising by the "oppressed" people in South Vietnam would lead to a general uprising and overthrow of the "puppet" regime supported by the United States.
The city of Hue was the only city to be completely occupied by the communist forces during the massive offensive, and was the scene of violent and close-quarter fighting that waged for nearly a month, from January 31st to February 25th, 1968. The general uprising never occurred, and in fact the communist's disappointment led to atrocities when they massacred hundreds of "collaborators" after they took control. The fighting to retake control of the city and oust the NVA and VC devastated the city and Imperial Palace, symbolizing the tragic and confused nature of the war.

Players are cast in the roles of the commanders of each side's forces. Both players will have capabilities to inflict harm upon their opponent, while also having liabilities to protect. Contestants will be challenged to do as well, or better than, their historical counterparts.

Game Scale: The map scale is about 350-400 yards per inch.
Each combat unit represents a platoon (25 to 30 men, 2 tanks or 6 APCs (Armored Personnel Carriers) and artillery batteries (M-109, Katyusha rockets, and mortars).
A game turn represents 2-3 days of time.

boardgame.name: Cooperation
boardgame.description:
The goal of this little roll-and-move game is for players to work together to make it to the finish line. Along the way, they have some choices to make as to whether to which path to take and whether to remain together or to go their separate ways. Depending upon where they land, they can draw Gold, Disaster, or Frustration cards that affect them depending on whether they are still with their partner. The goal of the game is to be the player holding the least chips when the finish line is reached.

Per manufacturer advertisement:

"Cooperation? is a hilarious experience. It lets you scheme, practice being crafty, have fun with disaster. Once you've betrayed your partner - and you probably will - watch out! If you choose to cooperate . . . beware!

Cooperation? stands unique among games. It's aim is to beat you, and, since all players are facing this same obstacle, someone has to be the winner.

Score Cooperation? high in entertainment. It's the kind of a game you will want to bring out at a party . . . and all ages can play. Four to six players, in teams of two. You will experience hours of fun and relaxation. "
